title: 104_hr2439
content: The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" allows states to use State infrastructure banks for financing transportation projects, recognizing the need for new financial concepts and more freedom in developing public-private transportation partnerships. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" defines key terms such as Secretary, State, and State infrastructure bank. State infrastructure banks are created at the State or multi-State level to finance transportation projects. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" grants consent to States to establish State infrastructure banks through interstate compacts to promote regional investment in transportation infrastructure. These banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to entities for eligible transportation projects under federal laws. State infrastructure banks can provide financial assistance to public or private entities for transportation projects under federal laws. Assistance may include loans or other forms of support for project construction costs, which can be subordinated to other project financing. "Other assistance" may involve credit enhancements, capital reserves, or financing issuance costs. The term "other assistance" in this subsection includes various forms of financial support for transportation projects, such as credit enhancements, capital reserves, and financing issuance costs. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, each participating State must maintain an investment grade rating on its debt issuances or have sufficient insurance for its financing instruments. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, each participating State must maintain an investment grade rating on its debt issuances or have sufficient insurance for its financing instruments. The bank must ensure that investment income generated by deposited funds will be credited to the bank, available for use in providing loans for transportation projects, and invested in Treasury securities or other financing instruments to earn interest. Repayment of loans or assistance to a State may be provided from loans under this Act. The Secretary may provide interest-earning funds to enhance transportation projects, programs, and activities. Repayment of loans from the bank can be credited or used for the same purpose as the loaned funds. Loans will bear appropriate interest determined by the bank and repayment must start within 5 years of project completion. The repayment term for any loan will not exceed 30 years. The Secretary must ensure that loan repayment does not exceed 30 years and limit transfers to the bank. The bank must provide an annual status report to the Secretary. Federal disbursements for capital reserves should align with historic rates. Specific procedures and guidelines for establishing projects must be specified by the Secretary. The Secretary must ensure Federal disbursements for capital reserves align with historic rates and specify procedures for State infrastructure bank loans. States can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds to the bank and disburse them at a controlled rate. The State infrastructure bank can receive funds transferred from Federal apportionments at a controlled rate, not exceeding the traditional disbursement rate for the Federal-aid highway program. The deposit of funds does not create any obligation or guarantee on the part of the United States, and any financing instrument issued by the bank must explicitly state that it is not backed by the United States. The State infrastructure bank can receive Federal funds without creating any obligation or guarantee from the United States. State funds can also be contributed for bank administration costs, not exceeding 2 percent of the Federal funds deposited.
